latest news.eng_title: Significant Fluctuations in US Stock Market
latest news.summary: The US stock market experienced significant fluctuations as investors digested the latest inflation reports, which showed a 2.5% increase in August. The NASDAQ attempted to stabilize as traders took advantage of opportunities in technology stocks. The main Wall Street indices declined as uncertainty grew about the Federal Reserve's (US central bank) interest rate path following the latest inflation data. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 650 points, the S&P 500 index dropped 1.5%, and the NASDAQ composite index declined 0.70%. Meanwhile, shares of Intel and Apple rose by over 2% and 1% respectively, while shares of UnitedHealth Group, Goldman Sachs, and Amgen contributed to the decline in the Dow Jones.
latest news.title: تقلبات قوية في وول ستريت .. وداو جونز يفقد 650 نقطة

latest news.eng_title: U.S. shares mixed at close of trade; Dow Jones Industrial Average down 0.23% By Investing.com
latest news.summary: The US stock market closed with mixed results, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 0.23%. The worst performers were Edgio Inc, down 38.36% to $0.75, Painreform Ltd, down 33.33% to $1.06, and Singularity Future Technology Ltd, down 32.16% to $1.73. In contrast, 1439 stocks advanced, while 1355 fell, and 108 remained unchanged. The CBOE Volatility Index decreased by 1.90% to 19.08. In commodities trading, Gold Futures rose 0.50% to $2,545.45 per troy ounce, while Crude oil and Brent oil contracts fell by 3.46% and 2.99%, respectively.
latest news.title: U.S. shares mixed at close of trade; Dow Jones Industrial Average down 0.23% By Investing.com

latest news.summary: Intel's stock price dropped 1.5% on Tuesday, trading as low as $18.70 and closing at $18.79. The company's revenue for the quarter was down 0.8% compared to the same quarter last year, and the firm had a net margin of 1.77%. Several research firms have issued reports on Intel, including Roth Mkm, The Goldman Sachs Group, Mizuho, and Hsbc Global Res, which have all reduced their price targets and ratings on the stock. According to MarketBeat.com, Intel has an average rating of 'Hold' and a consensus price target of $32.04. The company has a market capitalization of $80.30 billion and a P/E ratio of 19.57. CEO Patrick P. Gelsinger purchased 12,500 shares of the stock on August 5th, valued at approximately $252,000.00.
latest news.title: Intel (NASDAQ:INTC) Trading Down 1.5%

latest news.summary: Stocks may have peaked last week, according to some investors, as the S&P 500's (IVV) returns typically decline in September and October. The chart indicated a bearish double top at 5,670, and the 200-day moving average is below 5,200, which could be the next support zone. Nvidia (NVDA) led the tech sector lower, losing 12.55%, while Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) dropped by 7.66%. In the energy sector, Chevron (CVX) lost 6% and ConocoPhillips (COP) dropped by 7.3%, due to concerns over OPEC's output and a resolution to the war in Israel. Weak oil prices suggest a weakening global economy, and China's economic slump is also hurting oil prices. As a result, investors may find better bargains in the next two months as stock prices trade lower. 'Chances are high that stocks peaked last week,' according to the article. 'Stock chart technicians would refer to the 200-day moving average below 5,200 as the next support zone,' it is also mentioned. 'Customers prefer to wait for Nvidia's Blackwell server AI release over AMD's MI 300 AI servers,' and 'Nvidia dominates AMD with its RTX 40 series' in the PC market.
latest news.title: Did Stocks Peak Last Week?

latest news.eng_title: The Fleeting Nature of Companies: A Look at the Decline of General Electric and Intel
latest news.summary: The average lifespan of a company in Mexico is 7.8 years, while in the EU it is 19.6 years and in the US it is around 20 years. Companies like General Electric and those mentioned in James C. Collins' book 'Empresas que sobresalen' have shown significant decline. Intel, a multinational semiconductor and circuit company, has seen a 62% drop in its stock price this year and is at risk of being removed from the Dow Jones index. The author suggests that the decline of companies may be due to the transience of human existence and the influence of factors like luck and serendipity. Daniel Kahneman argues that success in business is often influenced by chance rather than strategic decisions. The author concludes that the decline of companies is a natural process, and that the concept of 'luck' can be seen as the meeting of preparation and opportunity.
latest news.title: Rogelio Segovia: Las empresas desaparecen, ¿adiós Intel?

latest news.eng_title: Stocks recover as markets step back from AI: Market Takeaways
latest news.summary: US stocks (^DJI, ^IXIC, ^GSPC) recovered from last week's volatility and tech sell-offs in today's session. Yahoo Finance markets reporter Josh Schafer notes that the broad participation across sectors, including the S&P 500, which was up over 1%, is a positive sign. Schafer says, 'It's probably a good thing for some investors to see what we see when we look at the intraday coming off the bottom to see all those other sectors participating.' He also notes that the market rally is not just about AI, citing charts from Laurie Cavatina that show the top 10 stocks are no longer significantly outperforming the S&P 500. Schafer says, 'We're not just talking about AI earnings and AI spending. There's some other things I think moving capital, FCP, I fed, CP, I fed weakening in the labour market.' He believes that the market is shifting its focus to macroeconomic factors, such as jobs reports, ahead of the Fed meeting next week.
latest news.title: Stocks recover as markets step back from AI: Market Takeaways

latest news.eng_title: Jim Cramer Says Intel Corporation (INTC) Has Been ‘Rocked By Key Defections'
latest news.summary: Jim Cramer discussed the recent economic data and its impact on the market. He noted that the S&P 500 is poised to fall for the fourth day in a row after the weaker-than-expected August jobs report. Despite this, the unemployment rate dropped to 4.2%, aligning with predictions. Cramer emphasized that September is historically a weak month for the market due to significant profit-taking. He encouraged investors to remain confident and avoid abandoning their positions due to these uncertainties. Cramer also discussed Intel Corporation (NASDAQ:INTC), which has been hit by major departures, including Stuart Pann and Shlomit Weiss. He noted that these challenges are making it harder for CEO Pat Gelsinger to execute his turnaround strategy at Intel Corporation (NASDAQ:INTC). However, Cramer believes that Intel Corporation (NASDAQ:INTC) is a strong investment for 2024 due to its strategic transformation, strong market presence, and growth potential in key areas.
latest news.title: Jim Cramer Says Intel Corporation (INTC) Has Been ‘Rocked By Key Defections'

latest news.eng_title: Intel, Southwest, and Boeing Have Had Brutal Starts to 2024. Can Any of Them Turn It Around? | The Motley Fool
latest news.summary: In this episode of Motley Fool Money, Dylan Lewis and Asit Sharma discuss the turnaround stories of Intel, Southwest, and Boeing. Intel has had a rough start to 2024, with a share price decline of around 58% and potential removal from the Dow Jones index. Asit Sharma believes that Intel needs to cut costs and become more competitive in the foundry business, which is a key area of investment for the company. He also notes that the company's dividend cut is a positive sign, but investors may not have the patience to wait for the company's turnaround. In contrast, Southwest Airlines has seen a boost in its share price after activist investor Elliott Management disclosed a 10% stake in the company. Asit believes that Southwest needs to become more efficient and upgrade its technology, but this may take time. Boeing, on the other hand, is facing a fresh downgrade and concerns over its Starliner space equipment. Asit notes that the company's cash flow is negative and it needs to raise capital to invest in its next generation of planes. He believes that Boeing's reputation risk is the toughest challenge for the company to overcome.
latest news.title: Intel, Southwest, and Boeing Have Had Brutal Starts to 2024. Can Any of Them Turn It Around? | The Motley Fool

latest news.eng_title: US Stock Market Stabilizes After Weak Week
latest news.summary: The US stock market has stabilized after a weak week, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 0.8% to 40,671 points. The S&P 500 also saw a 0.9% increase to 5,459 points, while the Nasdaq 100 rose 1.2% to 18,634 points. Boeing shares led the Dow with a 3.6% gain after the company reached an agreement with the largest union, IAM. Analysts praised the 25% wage increase, which was lower than the 40% originally demanded by IAM. In contrast, Merck & Co shares fell 2% due to positive data on a potential competitor to their lung cancer medication, Keytruda. Dell and Palantir shares rose 5% and 11% respectively, as they are set to be added to the S&P 500 index. Apple shares fell 0.8% as investors were cautious ahead of the company's new iPhone models, which will be unveiled at 19:00 CET and are expected to feature artificial intelligence technology.
latest news.title: US-Eröffnung: Kurse stabilisieren sich nach sehr schwacher Vorwoche

news knowledge.eng_title: Intel Stock Drops Further as Silicon Wafers Reportedly Fail Broadcom Tests
news knowledge.summary: Intel shares dropped further on Wednesday after Reuters reported that Broadcom's tests of Intel's 18A manufacturing process failed. The silicon wafers, which were run through the process, were reportedly returned to Broadcom last month. Intel's struggles have accelerated over the last month, with a disappointing earnings report and plans to lay off 15% of its employees. The company's shares have lost about 60% of their value since the start of 2024. Intel's shares were 2% lower at $19.67 early Wednesday afternoon. 'The earnings-related fall was followed by reports that concerns have emerged over the company's planned construction of two new facilities in Germany,' according to Investopedia. 'Executives are preparing to present plans to cut costs and sell assets amid the company's struggles, and concerns that Intel could potentially face removal from the Dow Jones Industrial Average (DJIA),' the article added.
news knowledge.title: Intel Stock Drops Further as Silicon Wafers Reportedly Fail Broadcom Tests

news knowledge.eng_title: DOW: Index May Drop Intel & Replace it With Nvidia
news knowledge.summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average may replace Intel with Nvidia due to Intel's poor performance. Intel's stock (INTC) has lost over 70% of its value since 2020, and the company has faced significant market share loss and workforce cuts. The Dow's selection committee considers the price of shares in the index, and currently, Nvidia's stock has spiked over 160% in the past year, making it a potential candidate for inclusion. If Intel is replaced, it could create positive momentum for Nvidia, as many funds indexed to the Dow would become net buyers.
news knowledge.title: DOW: Index May Drop Intel & Replace it With Nvidia

news knowledge.eng_title: Intel at Risk of Being Removed from Dow Jones Industrial Average
news knowledge.summary: Intel, one of the first tech companies to be included in the Dow Jones Industrial Average, is at risk of being removed from the index due to a significant decline in its stock price. The company's stock value has fallen by nearly 60% this year, making it the worst performer in the list. This decline is part of a broader trend in the semiconductor industry, with the Philadelphia SE Semiconductor index falling by 6% after reports of a global decline in chip sales in July 2024. In response to these challenges, Intel has suspended its dividend payments and announced plans to lay off 15% of its employees, according to Reuters. As Intel's stock price continues to plummet, the company's future in the Dow Jones Industrial Average remains uncertain.
news knowledge.title: Intel может вылететь из индекса Dow Jones из-за краха акций

news knowledge.eng_title: Intel's Place In Dow In Jeopardy, AI Strategy Under Scrutiny: Report - Intel (NASDAQ:INTC)
news knowledge.summary: Analysts predict that Intel may be removed from the Dow Jones Industrial Average due to its struggles in AI and manufacturing competitiveness. According to Reuters, Intel's stock price trajectory and missed opportunities in the artificial intelligence boom, such as OpenAI's failed investment, have raised concerns. Ryuta Makino of Gabelli Funds suggests that Nvidia Corp could replace Intel on the Dow, citing Nvidia's 129% increase in the last 12 months compared to Intel's 44% decline. Daniel Morgan of Synovus Trust also notes Texas Instruments Inc as a possible contender for the Dow Jones. Intel plans to ship chips for over 100 million AI personal computers by 2025, but recent reports indicate the company is considering breaking up its product design and manufacturing businesses. As a result, Intel's stock price has dropped 6.63% to $20.58 at the last check on Tuesday.
news knowledge.title: Intel's Place In Dow In Jeopardy, AI Strategy Under Scrutiny: Report - Intel (NASDAQ:INTC)

news knowledge.eng_title: Dow drops nearly 1175 points on losses in shares of Intel, Goldman Sachs
news knowledge.summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped nearly 1175 points on Monday morning due to losses in shares of Intel and Goldman Sachs. Intel's shares fell $1.89 (8.8%) and those of Goldman Sachs dropped $25.34 (5.4%), resulting in a 179-point drag on the Dow. Apple and Microsoft are also contributing to the decline. According to the Dow's calculation, a $1 move in any of its 30 components results in a 6.57-point swing.
news knowledge.title: Dow drops nearly 1175 points on losses in shares of Intel, Goldman Sachs

news knowledge.eng_title: Is Intel at risk of getting booted from the Dow?
news knowledge.summary: Intel's (INTC) shares have plummeted nearly 30% after the company announced a cost reduction plan and reported weaker earnings. This has raised concerns about whether Intel will be removed from the Dow Jones Industrial Average (^DJI). However, Barron's senior market analysis writer Paul La Monica suggests that this might not happen immediately, stating 'It wouldn't surprise me if sometime in 2025 there is a decision to be made.' La Monica also mentioned that Qualcomm (QCOM), Broadcom (AVGO), and Nvidia (NVDA) could potentially replace Intel in the index, citing recent stock splits from Nvidia and Broadcom as a factor in their favor.
news knowledge.title: Is Intel at risk of getting booted from the Dow?

news knowledge.eng_title: Dow drops 600 on weak jobs data as a global sell-off whips back to Wall Street
news knowledge.summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 600 points on Friday due to weak jobs data, which sparked a global sell-off that reached Wall Street. The S&P 500 fell 1.8%, the Dow Jones lost 1.5%, and the Nasdaq composite fell 2.4%. The decline was triggered by a report showing slower-than-expected hiring by U.S. employers, causing market fears. Intel's stock plummeted to its worst day in 50 years after reporting disappointing profits and suspending its dividend, while Treasury yields fell as investors anticipated the Federal Reserve's potential rate cuts in September.
news knowledge.title: Dow drops 600 on weak jobs data as a global sell-off whips back to Wall Street

news knowledge.eng_title: Stock market news today: Nasdaq falls 10% from record high after disappointing jobs report
news knowledge.summary: US stocks plummeted on Friday after the July jobs report showed a cooling labor market, fueling concerns that the Federal Reserve's 'higher for longer' interest-rate stance might lead to a recession. The Nasdaq Composite dropped 2.6%, the Dow Jones Industrial Average slumped 1%, and the S&P 500 sank 1.5%. Intel's disastrous earnings and weak profit guidance from Amazon added to the pressure on stocks, with Intel shares plummeting over 25% and Amazon stock sliding almost 10%. Intel CEO Pat Gelsinger said, 'This is the biggest restructuring of Intel I'd say since the memory microprocessor decision four decades ago.' The US economy added just 114,000 new jobs last month, and the unemployment rate unexpectedly rose to 4.3%, the highest since October 2021. Wage growth slowed to 0.2% month-on-month and 3.6% year-over-year, while the underemployment rate rose to 7.8%.
news knowledge.title: Stock market news today: Nasdaq falls 10% from record high after disappointing jobs report

news knowledge.eng_title: Wall Street Plunges as Intel and Recession Fears Weigh on Investors
news knowledge.summary: Wall Street fell by over 2% at the close of trading, led by Intel's 26% drop and renewed fears of recession following negative labor market data in the US. The tech-heavy Nasdaq index fell 2.26% to 16,805 points, followed by the Dow Jones Industrial Average (-2.07%, 39,511) and the S&P 500 (-2.02%, 5,336). Intel plummeted after announcing poor quarterly results, including losses and reduced revenue due to increased competition in the chip market, as well as a $10 billion cost-cutting plan by 2025 that includes the layoff of 15,000 employees. Amazon, the e-commerce giant, was also heavily affected, losing nearly 9% after releasing quarterly earnings that failed to meet expectations and issuing disappointing forecasts. Investors rushed to sell stocks after receiving the latest US labor report, which showed slower-than-expected job growth in July and a 4.3% unemployment rate, the highest since October 2021. The market had been boosted on Wednesday by the Federal Reserve's suggestion that interest rate cuts may be imminent, but on Friday, investors valued the possibility of a 'hard landing' in the economy due to high interest rates. According to Bret Kenwell, an investment analyst at eToro, 'investors assume at least one rate cut in September,' but after the weak employment report, 'the situation shifts from 'if' the Fed will cut rates to 'how much' they will cut.' Joaquín Robles, a market analyst, noted that a 'correction of 5-15% should not be a major concern for investors, as many will be motivated to take profits after recent gains and the fear of economic cooling.'
news knowledge.title: Wall Street cae un 2 % a media sesión, arrastrado por Intel y los temores de recesión Infobae

news knowledge.eng_title: Wall Street Plunges as Intel and Recession Fears Weigh on Markets
news knowledge.summary: Wall Street plummeted by over 2% at the close of trading, led by Intel's 26% decline and renewed fears of recession triggered by negative US labor market data. The Nasdaq fell 2.26%, the Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 2.07%, and the S&P 500 declined 2.02%. Intel's stock plummeted after announcing poor quarterly results, including losses and reduced revenue due to increased competition in the chip market, as well as a $10 billion cost-cutting plan by 2025, which includes the layoff of 15,000 employees. Amazon, the e-commerce giant, was also heavily impacted, losing nearly 9% after releasing quarterly earnings and forecasts that failed to meet expectations. Investors sold stocks after receiving the latest US labor report, which showed slower-than-expected job growth in July and a 4.3% unemployment rate, the highest since October 2021. The market had rallied on Wednesday after the Federal Reserve suggested that interest rate cuts may be imminent, but on Friday, investors valued the possibility of a 'hard landing' in the economy due to high interest rates. According to Bret Kenwell, eToro's investment analyst, 'investors assume at least one rate cut in September', but after the weak employment report, 'the situation shifts from 'will the Fed cut rates' to 'how much will they cut'.' Joaquín Robles, market analyst, noted that a 'correction between 5% and 15% should not be a major concern for investors, as many will be motivated to take profits after recent gains and the fear of economic cooling.' The Vix index, known as the 'fear gauge', surged 45% in this session, after rising 12% on Thursday.
news knowledge.title: Wall Street cae un 2 % a media sesión, arrastrado por Intel y los temores de recesión
